articles.author: Dr Ghamz E Ali Siyal
articles.summary: In the Climate Risk Index 2025, Pakistan moved from eighth to first place as the most affected country by climate related events. Unicef ranked Pakistan among the top 15 countries where children are extremely vulnerable to climate change and environmental stresses and shocks. The current monsoon season has led to hundreds of deaths in Punjab. Tharparkar, Dera Bugti, Washuk, Qilla Abdullah, Harnai, Barkhan, Thatta, Sujawal, Umerkot and Nasirabad are the ten most vulnerable districts for children.

articles.title: La Nina may return to impact climate patterns from Sept onward: WMO
articles.author: Amin Ahmed
articles.summary: La Nina may return to impact weather and climate patterns from September onward, according to the latest World Meteorological Organisation update. However, temperatures are still expected to be above average for much of the world. The UN agency's forecast for the El Niño Southern Oscillation phenomenon is an important climate intelligence tool.

articles.title: Natural Disasters or Self-Inflicted Wounds?
articles.author: Colonel Naveed Safdar
articles.summary: The 2025 floods in Pakistan have been the most severe since 1988, with over 820 lives lost, around 1200 injured, and 250,000 to 300,000 displaced in Punjab alone. More than 7225 homes have been damaged, 5548 livestock perished, and over 350,000 acres of cultivable land have been submerged. Pakistan has only 150 dams, many of which are small, outdated, and grossly insufficient for the storage of water. India released over one million cusecs of water into the Chenab and 245,000 cusec into the Sutlej in recent weeks.

articles.title: Why trees in Warrington have been losing their leaves early this year
articles.author: Ella Wilcox
articles.summary: Leaves have been falling from trees across Warrington for some weeks already. This is due to the heatwave this summer and the lack of rainfall. The Met Office predicts it will be the hottest summer on UK record this year. Ralph Connolly, woodlands lead at Cheshire Wildlife Trust, explains that trees are losing their leaves early this year because of the adverse weather conditions.

articles.title: Australia should ignore UN on ‘net zero'
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: UN climate director Simon Stiell flew to Australia to talk about climate change. He warned that Australia will cause the world to 'overheat' if it does not increase its clean-energy aspirations. He also warned that unambitious interim aims would undermine Australia's high living standards and make the present grocery pricing situation look like a picnic.

articles.title: Deadly H5 bird flu risk increases in Australia in spring, experts warn
articles.author: Jane McNaughton
articles.summary: The arrival of spring heralds the annual bird migration. There are fears that the H5 strain of bird flu will infect Australia for the first time. Australia has been preparing for an incursion of H5 bird flu for years, with a $95 million suite of biosecurity, environmental and public health funding announced in October.

articles.title: Ocean of motion: Modeling coastal flood risks
articles.author: Phys Dot Org

articles.author: Graham J Dwyer
articles.summary: Ireland has a moderate climate with few temperature extremes. The recent severe storms remind us that climate change is a serious threat to wellbeing and, in the longer term, the survival of human life as we know it. Around 40% of the Irish population lives within a few miles of the coast. Key industries such as tourism, fisheries, and aquaculture are exposed to disruption. There is no shortage of climate change awareness in Ireland, but awareness alone does not translate into urgent action.
